description: From Latin nūmen (“nod of the head; divine sway or will; divinity”)  +‎ -ous (“suffix forming adjectives from nouns, denoting possession or presence of a quality”). Nūmen is believed to derive either from Latin *nuō (“to nod”) or from Ancient Greek νοούμενον (nooúmenon, “influence perceptible by the mind but not the senses”) (ultimately from νόος (nóos, “mind; thought; purpose”)).

adjectives.description: numinous (comparative more numinous, superlative most numinous)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to a numen (divinity); indicating the presence of a divinity. [from mid 17th c.]
examples: His interest in numinous objects led him on a quest for the Holy Grail.

entries.meaning: Evoking a sense of the mystical, sublime, or transcendent; awe-inspiring.
